body: A CHARTER bus from Holyoke, Mass., was parked outside Lou Newkirk's antiques shop in the Port Morris section of the Bronx on a recent raw Saturday afternoon. Inside, Anne Tracy and her daughter, Becky, from Berkshire, Mass., were browsing. The bus driver, Gary Despres, had deposited other in-town-for-the-day shoppers from Massachusetts in midtown
title: A Bronx Antiques Row Brings Hope for Renewal

body: Asked just a year ago whether they would have supported legislation to severely curtail the power of community school boards, many parents and teachers in District 15 in Brooklyn would have answered loudly in the negative. The district, which straddles working-class neighborhoods in South Brooklyn and more affluent brownstone blocks in Park Slope,
title: In South Brooklyn, Guarded Desire for Change

body: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew will be able to use his new power to hire school superintendents almost immediately in 27 of the city's 32 school districts. The timing of the legislation enacted yesterday coincides with the final months of three-year contracts between all the local school boards and their district superintendents. Five local school
title: Timing Allows Crew To Respond Quickly

body: Fred Kaplan is one of those inveterate New Yorkers, a street-smart kid from Bensonhurst who used to roller-skate to Coney Island and ride the subway into Manhattan to ice-skate in Central Park, who went on to become a well-known literary biographer and scholar firmly rooted in the City University system. Over the years, he could be found poring
title: Urban Life, Urban Danger: Scholar Stabbed on the Subway

body: Kathryn Falk, the self-styled Queen of Romance, looked decidedly unromantic on a recent morning in Brooklyn, swigging cough syrup from the bottle and padding about her romance-magazine offices in Kmart slippers. She gave a visitor a quick tour of Romantic Times Magazine, from her display of erotic Chinese silk shoes -- a few inches long, for bound
title: A Magazine for Romance Novels And the Women Who Love Them

body: In the face of an emotional volley of criticism from parents, teachers and politicians, members of Community School Board 15 voted Wednesday to invite educators to apply for the job of district superintendent. The 5-to-3 vote by the board, with one abstention, effectively ends the nine-year tenure of Superintendent William Casey, who is widely
title: Vote Underlines District Split

body: Eileen C. Dugan, a Brooklyn Democrat who was elected to her ninth term in the New York State Assembly only on Tuesday, died yesterday at Beth Israel Medical Center. Ms. Dugan, who lived in Carroll Gardens, was 51. The cause was breast cancer, according to her family. Gov. George E. Pataki, who served in the Assembly with Ms. Dugan, ordered state
title: Eileen C. Dugan, 51, State Assemblywoman

body: Just south of the Atlantic Avenue railway station, where city-owned urban renewal property sat vacant for 30 years, a new complex of oversized suburban-style stores is to open next week. Six blocks away, on Adams Street, workers just broke ground for Brooklyn's first new hotel in 50 years. Across from the hotel site, which is still just a hole in
title: Growth in Downtown Brooklyn Is Still Looking Up, Planners Say

body: THREE years ago, Alan Marks, a Park Slope real-estate agent, would watch a one-bedroom apartment on Sackett Street, in an area known as the Lower Slope, languish on his list of rentals for longer than a month. Prospective tenants would take one look at the block, dotted with abandoned buildings and a few scraggly trees, turn up their noses and keep
title: The Boom in Park Slope

body: Sure, sure. We know. There's just not enough time in the day, the month, the whole year, for that matter. You would love to exercise, plow through books, play an instrument, learn a foreign language. You'd even floss your teeth if you had more time. But hey, there is only one of you. You have a demanding job, a busy schedule and you've got to sleep
title: Not Enough Time in a Day? Meet the Master Jugglers

body: Great Moments in 'D.I.Y.' History 1982: Gracie Mansion, a D.I.Y. forerunner, shows artists like David Wojnarowicz in a former East Village beauty shop. 1990-91: The art crash sends the New York gallery world into a slump, providing an opening for the huddled masses of excluded dealers and artists. October 1991: D.I.Y. invades cyberspace with ''The
title: The Do-It-Yourself Art World

body: New York City will make its first major service cut in recycling next month when it scales back collections for half the city's households. The reduction -- from weekly to alternate week pickups -- is the first tangible effect of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's $26 million cut to the city's recycling budget. The change is to begin Sept. 9. The Mayor
title: New Yorkers Face 2 Weeks of Storing Trash for Recycling

title: Residential Resales

body: Unraveling the mystery of the crash of T.W.A. Flight 800 is as sophisticated as a high-tech underwater device being shipped to the scene to listen for the electronic beep of the missing flight data recorder. And it's as simple as investigators knocking on doors along the Long Island coastline to ask if anyone saw anything unusual in the sky.
title: THE CRASH OF FLIGHT 800: THE INVESTIGATION;Searching for Clues On Countless Fronts

body: "JUMBALAYA," Nuyorican Poets Cafe, 236 East Third Street, Lower East Side. Readings and a forum titled "Are the Media Designing Colored Intellectuals?" Sunday at 2 P.M. Admission: $5. Information: (212) 674-3778. NEW PRESS POETRY READINGS, open readings and scheduled speakers at several locations around New York City. Tomorrow at 1 P.M., David
title: The Spoken Word

body: Though large bookstore chains have put down anchor in many New York City neighborhoods, independent bookstores of almost every genre continue to thrive. This despite the fact, reported recently by Bernard E. Rath, executive director of the American Booksellers Association, that more than 100 independent bookstores closed nationwide in the last two
title: Bookstores That Specialize, Succeed

body: Pucks and Racquets American Institute of Graphic Arts, 164 Fifth Avenue, at21st Street; (212) 807-1990. title: Calendar: Exhibitions, Tours and a Conference

body: Chefs Come to Fairway Fairway Market, 2328 Broadway (133d Street), will start a series of chefs' cooking classes tonight, from 8 to 9, with Matthew Kenney of Matthew's and Mezze. On May 15, Anne Rosenzweig of Arcadia and the Lobster Club will teach, followed on May 22 by Rafael Palomina of Inca Grill and on May 29 by John Villa of Judson Grill. The
title: Food Notes

body: A 34-year-old man was arrested and charged yesterday with beating and robbing a Brooklyn couple, and attempting to rape the woman, the police said. The suspect, Alexander Burgess, of 185 Nevins Street in Brooklyn, was arrested at 2:30 P.M., shortly after the police responded to several 911 calls about screams coming from the couple's fourth-floor
title: Man Charged in Assault of Brooklyn Couple

body: Locally produced maple syrup, maple candy and cheddar cheese are staples in many Vermont markets. And they are the staples of the first business venture among four friends who decided that there was a market for them in Brooklyn. The four -- Howard and Stephan Cantor and Adam Parke, who all live in Vermont, and Michael Romanashyn, a Brooklynite --
title: NEW YORKERS & CO.;Market and Pharmacy Specialize in Vermont

body: Of all the descriptions that capture the vastness of the New York City public school system, perhaps none is as telling as this: It took officials until noon yesterday, a full six months after the opening of school, to complete the count of every student enrolled for the year. It is 1,056,251, an increase of 23,109 over the previous school year.
title: After 6 Months, Schools Know Their Enrollments

body: When Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and fire officials first proposed shutting down New York City's fire alarm boxes more than a year ago, they said it would reduce false alarms and save $5 million a year. New Yorkers, they added, would be better served by the city's modern, expansive telephone system than by its antiquated network of 16,300 alarm
title: Phone Scarcity Complicates Fire Alarm Plan

body: IT was a few days after the violent robbery that had killed Abdul Kareem Alsahybi in his Brooklyn delicatessen. The store was closed, bags filled with bullet-riddled cigarette packs and other evidence clogged the aisle, and Mr. Alsahybi's blood still stained the floor. But the lottery machine, destroyed in the shootout on Friday night, had already
title: Metro Matters;Death in Deli And Worries Over Lottery

body: A Brooklyn delicatessen owner was shot to death on Friday during a robbery in his store minutes before he was to close it for the night, the police said. The killers fled with the day's receipts. The store owner, Abdul Kareem Alsahybi, 48, who lived in Cobble Hill with his wife and seven children, left his native Yemen more than 20 years ago with
title: Delicatessen Owner Is Shot to Death In Brooklyn Robbery

body: FOR the third time, Carol Link caresses a Noritake tea cup with an elaborate red and gold design. It's part of a set of china (service for six with extra serving plates) selling at the Harlem Restoration Thrift Shop for $150, a price that makes her think the unthinkable. "I already own two sets of china," she mumbles, "but I certainly don't own
title: The Thrift Shop Steps Up in Class

body: The declaration was of triumph, if not total independence: Sanitation Department officials, conceding that the gargantuan amounts of snow in the city still posed enduring problems, said nonetheless that every street in the city had been plowed by yesterday -- except for the several dozen streets blocked by abandoned cars. "One hundred percent,"
title: THE BLIZZARD OF 1996: PLOWING;Snowbanks Aside, the Sanitation Department Declares a Victory
